head.title: Finesse and mirror speed measurement for a suspended Fabry-Perot cavity using the ringing effect

article.h1: Finesse and mirror speed measurement for a suspended Fabry-Perot cavity using the ringing effect

span.span:
Laboratoire de l‚ÄôAcc√©l√©rateur Lin√©aire,
Universit√© Paris-Sud, Bat 208, 91405 Orsay (France)

div.p: We here present an investigation of the ringing effect observed on the VIRGO mode-cleaner prototype MC30. The results of a numerical calculation show how a simple empirical formula can determine the cavity expansion rate from the oscillatory behavior. We also show how the simulation output can be adjusted to estimate the finesse value of the suspended cavity.

span.span: ‚Ä†thanks: Pre.address: Observatoire C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur, B.P. 4229, 06304 Nice Cedex 4 (France)

div.p: Interferometric gravitational wave detectors, like VIRGO¬†[1], LIGO¬†[2], GEO¬†[3] and TAMA¬†[4], make use of suspended Fabry-Perot cavities for their properties: spatial filtering of the laser beam, optical path amplification and power recycling to name a few. Due to the suspension system, the motion of each mirror is dominated by oscillations at the pendulum‚Äôs fundamental resonance, typically below 1‚Å¢H‚Å¢z1ùêªùëßNUMBER:1 italic-H italic-z1\,Hz and with amplitudes as large as tens of a laser wavelength.

A VIRGO mode-cleaner prototype MC30 [5], which operated in Orsay for several years, consists of a 30‚Å¢m30ùëöNUMBER:30 italic-m30\,m triangular Fabry-Perot cavity with two possible finesse values, 100 or 1600, depending on the incoming laser beam polarization state. The two-stage suspension system, together with a local damping control system, results in a residual RMS displacement value, for each mirror, of 0.8‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m0.8ùúáùëöNUMBER:0.8 italic-mu italic-m0.8\,\mu m.

Prior to the lock acquisition, the cavity length sweeps the optical resonance at different rates of expansion. If the relative velocity between the mirrors is constant, the DC transmitted power delineates the Airy peak as a function of time, easily observed for the optical system with ‚Ñ±=100‚Ñ±100caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:100{\cal F}=100. However, in the case of ‚Ñ±=1600‚Ñ±1600caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:1600{\cal F}=1600, a deformation of the Airy peak, similar to a ringing, was observed (see fig.(1)).

Both [6, 7], and references therein, discuss this phenomenon. Briefly, this effect arises once the cavity sweeps the optical resonance in a time œÑs‚Å¢wsubscriptùúèùë†ùë§italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{sw} of the order of or less than the cavity storage time œÑs‚Å¢t=2‚Å¢L0‚Å¢‚Ñ±/c‚Å¢œÄsubscriptùúèùë†ùë°2subscriptùêø0‚Ñ±ùëêùúãitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-F MULOP:divide italic-c italic-pi\tau_{st}=2\,L_{0}\,{\cal F}/c\,\pi, where L0=30‚Å¢msubscriptùêø030ùëöitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:30 italic-mL_{0}=30\,m is the cavity length and cùëêitalic-cc the speed of light.

This effect is observed when the rate of expansion is so high that, as resonance is approached, the cavity doesn‚Äôt have enough time to completely fill itself. It is the beating between the incoming laser field and the evolving stored field that gives rise to this oscillatory behavior.
The goal of this letter is to present the informations which can be extracted from such deformation, in particular, the finesse of the cavity and the relative mirror speed.

section.h2: 2 The ringing effect in Fabry-Perot cavities

div.p: The model used for this study is shown in fig.(2). Assuming a negligible mirror displacement for times of the order of the round trip time of light œÑ=2‚Å¢L0/c=0.2‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢sùúè2subscriptùêø0ùëê0.2ùúáùë†italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-c RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2 italic-mu italic-s\tau=2L_{0}/c=0.2\mu s, the stored field Œ®1‚Å¢(t)subscriptŒ®1ùë°Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\Psi_{1}(t) at time tùë°italic-tt can be written as

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-i italic-k italic-L CLOSE:) Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus italic-tau CLOSE:)

div.p: where r1subscriptùëü1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{1} and t1subscriptùë°1italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{1} denote the amplitude reflectivity and transmittivity of each mirror, Œ®i‚Å¢nsubscriptŒ®ùëñùëõPsi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Psi_{in} is the incoming laser field, and Lùêøitalic-LL is the cavity length. Assuming that the cavity expands at a constant rate vùë£italic-vv, we can write L=L0+v‚Å¢tùêøsubscriptùêø0ùë£ùë°italic-L RELOP:equals italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-v italic-tL=L_{0}+v\,t and solve eq.(1) iteratively, for different velocities vùë£italic-vv and finesse ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±caligraphic-F{\cal F}.

Fig.(3) shows the Airy peak for three velocities: v=0ùë£0italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0v=0 (static approximation), v=1‚Å¢Œª/sùë£1ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=1\lambda/s, and v=2.6‚Å¢Œª/sùë£2.6ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.6 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=2.6\lambda/s, with ‚Ñ±=4000‚Ñ±4000caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:4000{\cal F}=4000. The curve labeled static, corresponding to v=0ùë£0italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0v=0, was generated by neglecting the travel time of light, i.e the cavity has reached its equilibrium point at each step. The two other curves, on the other hand, were simulated according to the dynamical model here presented. Notice how the main peak height decreases, its width increases and its position shifts ahead of the resonance. These changes are greater for larger velocities.

We would now like to discuss a property of the ringing effect observed from the simulation runs. Fig.(3) graphs the stored power as a function of cavity length for a given finesse and for different values of velocity. We can now plot the stored power as a function of time, setting the velocity to a fixed value, but varying the finesse. One example is given in fig.(4). The top graph of this figure shows the stored power as a function of time, for an expansion rate set to v=10‚Å¢Œª/sùë£10ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=10\lambda/s, for three different finesse values: ‚Ñ±=1000‚Ñ±1000caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:1000{\cal F}=1000, 20002000NUMBER:20002000, and 30003000NUMBER:30003000. The bottom graph is the curves‚Äô time derivative. From these plots, we remark a particular characteristic of the phenomenon: the position of the minima and maxima, with the exception of the main peak, are almost independent from the finesse value.

Furthermore, going back to fig.(3), we can now note that the derivative zeros depend only on the relative mirror velocity. The simulation output shown in fig.(4) not only shows how the derivative zeros are independent, at least to first approximation, from the finesse, but it also shows a particular regularity in the spacing between the minima and maxima.

The upper graph of fig.(5) shows the simulated stored power of a cavity with ‚Ñ±=3500‚Ñ±3500caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:3500{\cal F}=3500, expanding at a rate 10‚Å¢Œª/s10ùúÜùë†NUMBER:10 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-s10\lambda/s. Let the position of the curve‚Äôs derivative zeros, tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢osubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëúitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{zero}, be labeled by the index nùëõitalic-nn, so that, for the first zero, positioned at tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢o‚âÉ5.07‚Å¢m‚Å¢ssimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëú5.07ùëöùë†italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:5.07 italic-m italic-st_{zero}\simeq 5.07ms, n=0ùëõ0italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0n=0, for the second zero, located at tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢o‚âÉ5.103‚Å¢m‚Å¢ssimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëú5.103ùëöùë†italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:5.103 italic-m italic-st_{zero}\simeq 5.103ms, n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1 and so on. Then, the bottom graph of fig.(5) shows the plot of index nùëõitalic-nn as a function of time. We remark that the nùëõitalic-nn-th zero of the derivative is a quadratic function of the zero crossing time tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢osubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëúitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{zero}: n‚àùtz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢o2proportional-toùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëú2italic-n RELOP:proportional-to italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn\propto t_{zero}^{2}. By fitting the simulation outputs to the expression nz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢o=p1+p2‚Å¢tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢o+p3‚Å¢tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢o2subscriptùëõùëßùëíùëüùëúsubscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2subscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëúsubscriptùëù3superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëú2italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn_{zero}=p_{1}+p_{2}t_{zero}+p_{3}t_{zero}^{2} where p1,2,3subscriptùëù123italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endp_{1,2,3} are fitting parameters, we empirically found that the coefficient p3subscriptùëù3italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endp_{3} can be written as p3=c‚Å¢v/Œª‚Å¢Lsubscriptùëù3ùëêùë£ùúÜùêøitalic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-c italic-v MULOP:divide italic-lambda italic-Lp_{3}=cv/\lambda L where Lùêøitalic-LL is the cavity length and vùë£italic-vv is the cavity expansion rate (an example is shown in the bottom graph of fig.(5)). Therefore, an estimate of coefficient p3subscriptùëù3italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endp_{3} would also give us an estimate of the relative velocity vùë£italic-vv.

Fig.(6) shows the results of a fit on a measured event. Notice how the parabolic behavior is in agreement with the experimental points, resulting in a measured speed of 12.8¬±10-2‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/splus-or-minus12.8superscript102ùúáùëöùë†NUMBER:12.8 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-mu italic-m MULOP:divide italic-s12.8\pm 10^{-2}\mu m/s.

Once the speed is extracted, it is possible to fit the measurements with the simulation‚Äôs output to find the remaining parameter: the finesse. The fit results of a set of measurements, six of which are shown in fig.(7), led to a mean finesse of ‚Ñ±¬Ø=1554¬±160¬Ø‚Ñ±plus-or-minus1554160OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-F ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1554 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:160\overline{{\cal F}}=1554\pm 160, a value later confirmed by a measurement of the cavity pole. The ten percent precision on the finesse measurement is most probably due to the alignment state of the cavity, as suggested by simulation studies.

An analysis of the optical ringing effect, observed on the VIRGO mode-cleaner prototype in Orsay, was here presented. We investigated a method to extract, from the oscillatory behavior, both the relative mirror speed and the finesse of the system.

The numerical results showed how the position of the oscillations‚Äô minima and maxima, when plotted as a function of time, weakly depend on the finesse value and are completely determined by the cavity expansion rate as the resonance is being crossed. In particular, we showed how a simple empirical formula can determine the cavity expansion rate by observing these minima and maxima.

Once the speed was reconstructed, it was possible to fit the measurements with the simulation‚Äôs output and estimate the cavity‚Äôs finesse to ‚Ñ±¬Ø=1554¬±160¬Ø‚Ñ±plus-or-minus1554160OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-F ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1554 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:160\overline{{\cal F}}=1554\pm 160.

The present letter gives an alternative method to the finesse measurement for a suspended cavity. The simplicity in the velocity reconstruction algorithm may be useful for a future control system capable of guiding the cavity into lock.

li.span: C. Bradaschia et al, Nucl. Intrum. Meth. Phys. Res. A 289, 518 (1990).
K. Danzmann et al, Internal Report MPQ 190 (1994).
N.Kanda et al, Proceedings of second Workshop of Gravitational Wave Data Analysis, Orsay 1997
M.Barsuglia et al., submitted to Rev.Sci.In
S. T‚ÄôJampens, Rapport de Stage de Licence au LAL (1996)

div.p: Fig.1: The observed ringing effect on the transmitted DC power of the MC30 prototype. The transmitted power is shown as a function of time as the cavity length sweeps the optical resonance at an unknown rate.
Fig.2: The model used for the study of the MC30 ringing effect.

Fig.3: The calculated Fabry-Perot transmitted power, with ‚Ñ±=4000‚Ñ±4000caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:4000{\cal F}=4000, as a function of cavity length Œî‚Å¢LŒîùêøDelta italic-L\Delta L as the resonance is swept at v=0ùë£0italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0v=0 (static approximation), v=1‚Å¢Œª/sùë£1ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=1\lambda/s, and v=2.6‚Å¢Œª/sùë£2.6ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.6 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=2.6\lambda/s. In the figure, Œî‚Å¢L=0Œîùêø0Delta italic-L RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta L=0 corresponds to resonance.

Fig.4: The calculated stored power as a function of time, with a fixed expansion rate set to v=10‚Å¢Œª/sùë£10ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=10\lambda/s, for different finesse values: ‚Ñ±=1000‚Ñ±1000caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:1000{\cal F}=1000, 20002000NUMBER:20002000, and 30003000NUMBER:30003000. Top graph: the stored power. Bottom graph: the stored power time derivative.

Fig.5: The simulated stored power of a Fabry-Perot, expanding at a constant rate v=10‚Å¢Œª/sùë£10ùúÜùë†italic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-sv=10\lambda/s, with ‚Ñ±=3500‚Ñ±3500caligraphic-F RELOP:equals NUMBER:3500{\cal F}=3500. Top graph: the stored power as a function of time. Bottom graph: the index nùëõitalic-nn, corresponding to the nùëõitalic-nn-th derivative zero, as a function of time. The curve is fit to the expression n=p1+p2‚Å¢t+p3‚Å¢t2ùëõsubscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2ùë°subscriptùëù3superscriptùë°2italic-n RELOP:equals italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn=p_{1}+p_{2}t+p_{3}t^{2}. Notice that p3=c‚Å¢v/Œª‚Å¢L=100‚Å¢[1/m‚Å¢s2]subscriptùëù3ùëêùë£ùúÜùêø100delimited-[]1ùëösuperscriptùë†2italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-c italic-v MULOP:divide italic-lambda italic-L RELOP:equals NUMBER:100 OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-m italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]p_{3}=cv/\lambda L=100[1/ms^{2}].

Fig.6: Fit results for the mirror relative velocity reconstruction.On the left: The measured DC transmitted power. On the right: the plot of tz‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢osubscriptùë°ùëßùëíùëüùëúitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z italic-e italic-r italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{zero} as a function of index nùëõitalic-nn. The error bars correspond to half of the oscilloscope‚Äôs sampling time. The reconstructed speed is 12.8¬±10-2‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/splus-or-minus12.8superscript102ùúáùëöùë†NUMBER:12.8 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-mu italic-m MULOP:divide italic-s12.8\pm 10^{-2}\mu m/s.

Fig.7: The observed ringing effect for the MC30 prototype: measurements and fits. The finesse and velocity values are shown for each graph. TD‚Å¢Csubscriptùëáùê∑ùê∂italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{DC} in arbitrary units.
